application.name: dsk2isis
application.brief: Converts NAIF DSK plate model to ISIS format
application.description: This application will convert a NAIF DSK plate model to an ISIS cube. Users must provide a valid map file to use for allocation of the ISIS cube. The scale and type of projection determine the size of the output cube.

history.change: Wrote tests. Added application to ISIS trunk. References #2035
Process data tiles instead of a pixel at a time; Test for valid output map coordinate at every map pixel. References #2035
Changed the category to Import and Export. Fixes #5188.

parameter.name: FROM
parameter.brief: Name of NAIF DSK DEM file
parameter.description: This parameter provides the name of the NAIF DSK file to convert to ISIS format. It is assumed to be in body fixed coordinates from which intersections for each output map grid point will be computed using NAIF's DSK toolkit.

parameter.name: MAP
parameter.brief: Name of file containing map description
parameter.description: This paramter provides the name of a file containing a valid map projection defintion. One can use the ISIS maptemplate application to create a map template.

parameter.name: TO
parameter.description: Name of the output ISIS file created by this application containing the rendering of the DSK DEM into and ISIS compatible DEM for use in the ISIS system.

description.p: This parameter provides two different methods to compute the output radius value for a given latitude, longitude map grid point.

option.brief: Ray intersection from image pixel location to DEM
option.description: Calculates an intercept location on the (irregularly shaped) body from the observer point (i.e., image pixel location) and look (or ray) direction

option.brief: Calculate using surface point latitude, longitude grid point
option.description: The radius value of the DEM is determined at the intercept point of the triaxial ellipsoid from the center of the body. This method extends the surface (x, y, z) body fixed coordinate of the ellisoid by extending the vector by a factor of 1.5. This creates the obsever point. The direction vector is then the negation of the observer point. From this, a DEM surface intercept point is determined.
